column2: On a student visa, you may work on campus part-time, typically up to 20 hours per week during the academic year and full-time during scheduled breaks and vacations.

column1: What is the procedure for acquiring an I-20?
column2: The procedure for acquiring an I-20 involves receiving a Form I-20 from the designated school official (DSO) at the university after being accepted into a SEVIS-approved program.

column1: How long does it take to acquire an I-20?
column2: The time it takes to acquire an I-20 varies but usually occurs after the student has been admitted to the program and provided the necessary documentation to the university.

column1: Can I get an electronic version of my I-20 form?
column2: It is not common to receive an electronic version of the I-20 form due to the physical signature requirement on the document.

column1: What information is required to fill out the I-20 form?
column2: Information required to fill out the I-20 form includes personal details, program of study, financial information, and other pertinent data needed for visa processing.

column1: Can I change my major or program of study once I've obtained my I-20?
column2: Changing your major or program of study after obtaining your I-20 may require updating the document with the designated school official (DSO) at the university.

column1: How may I receive an updated I-20 form if my program or personal information has changed?
column2: To receive an updated I-20 form due to program or personal information changes, you typically need to request the update from the designated school official (DSO) at the university.

column1: Can I use my I-20 paperwork to enter the United States many times?
column2: The I-20 form allows for multiple entries into the United States based on the student's program start date and duration.

column1: Is there an expiration date on my I-20?
column2: The I-20 form has an expiration date, typically corresponding to the end date of the program of study.

column1: Can I extend my I-20 form if I require additional time to complete my program?
column2: If needing additional time to complete your program, you may be able to extend your I-20 form by following the appropriate procedures and meeting the necessary requirements.

column1: How can I transfer my SEVIS data and I-20 form to another school?
column2: Transferring your SEVIS data and I-20 form to another school involves working with the designated school official (DSO) at both institutions and following the SEVIS transfer process outlined by U.S. immigration regulations.

column1: Do I need to have a specific quantity of money in my bank account to receive an I-20?
column2: Having a specific amount of money in your bank account is typically required to demonstrate financial capability for obtaining an I-20 form, showing you can cover tuition, living expenses, and other costs while studying in the U.S.

column1: Can I utilize my I-20 form to work off campus?
column2: You cannot use your I-20 form to work off-campus; employment authorization for international students is typically limited to on-campus jobs or approved practical training programs.

column1: What documents should I bring when I enter the United States with my I-20 form?
column2: When entering the United States with your I-20 form, you should bring essential documents including your valid passport, visa, I-20 form, admission letter from the university, financial documentation, and any other requested paperwork by U.S. Customs and Border Protection.

column1: Can I travel outside of the United States using an I-20 form?
column2: You can travel outside of the United States using an I-20 form, but it's essential to have a valid visa, passport, and endorsed travel signature from the designated school official (DSO) on your I-20 form before departing.

column1: How do I apply for a Social Security Number using my I-20 form?
column2: To apply for a Social Security Number using your I-20 form, you must first secure a job offer and receive employment authorization through Optional Practical Training (OPT) or Curricular Practical Training (CPT) approved by your designated school official (DSO).

column1: May I update the designated school official (DSO) indicated on my I-20 form?
column2: You cannot update the designated school official (DSO) indicated on your I-20 form; changes to your DSO require administrative updates by the university's international student office.

column1: What is the purpose of the SEVIS fee, and how may I pay?
column2: The SEVIS fee is paid to support the Student and Exchange Visitor Information System (SEVIS) that maintains immigration information on international students; you can pay the fee online through the SEVIS fee payment portal.

column1: Should I carry my I-20 form with me at all times while in the United States?
column2: While it's not required to carry your I-20 form at all times, you should have it available for immigration checks, travel, and employment verification if needed while in the U.S.

column1: Can I convert my I-20 form to a different visa category?
column2: You cannot convert your I-20 form to a different visa category; changing visa statuses typically requires completing specific application processes and meeting eligibility criteria for the desired visa category.

column1: How should I update my I-20 form if my financial status changes?
column2: If your financial status changes, you should inform your designated school official (DSO) at the university to update your I-20 form with the revised financial information.

column1: Can I use my I-20 to apply for a driver's license?
column2: You cannot use your I-20 form to apply for a driver's license; driver's license applications typically require additional documentation specific to the state's Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) requirements.

column1: What is the distinction between an I-20 form and an I-901 receipt?
column2: The I-20 form is issued to F-1 visa holders, while the I-901 receipt is used to confirm payment of the SEVIS fee required for F and J visa applicants.

column1: How can I apply for a visa using my I-20 form?
column2: To apply for a visa using your I-20 form, you must follow the visa application procedures outlined by the U.S. Department of State, including scheduling a visa interview at the nearest U.S. embassy or consulate.

column1: May I use my I-20 form to travel to countries other than the United States?
column2: You can use your I-20 form to travel to countries other than the United States, but it's essential to ensure you have the necessary visas and travel documents for those countries.

column1: How can I get a travel signature on my I-20 form?
column2: To get a travel signature on your I-20 form, you should contact your designated school official (DSO) before traveling abroad to request and receive an updated travel signature for re-entry into the U.S.

column1: May I get a digital signature on my I-20 form?
column2: While digital signatures are not typically accepted on I-20 forms, you may need to obtain a physical travel signature from your designated school official (DSO) for international travel.

column1: How can I renew my I-20 paperwork if it has expired?
column2: If your I-20 form has expired, you should work with your designated school official (DSO) to renew the document before the expiration date to maintain legal status in the U.S.

column1: What is the difference between the I-20 and DS-2019 forms?
column2: The I-20 form is for F-1 visa holders, while the DS-2019 form is for J-1 visa holders participating in exchange visitor programs, each serving different visa categories and programs.

column1: Can I use my I-20 to apply for a work permit?
column2: You cannot use your I-20 form to apply for a work permit; employment authorization typically requires separate applications, such as Optional Practical Training (OPT) or Curricular Practical Training (CPT).

column1: How can I update my I-20 form if my address changes in the United States?
column2: If your address changes in the U.S., you must inform your designated school official (DSO) promptly to update your I-20 form with the new address details.

column1: Can my husband and children be named on my I-20 form?
column2: Your husband and children can be named as dependents on your I-20 form if they plan to accompany you in the U.S. during your studies.

column1: How can I apply for a visa for my dependents using my I-20?
column2: To apply for visas for your dependents using your I-20, you would need to obtain dependent visas, such as F-2 visas for spouses and children under F-1 student visas.

column1: Can I get an I-20 form if I'm currently in the United States on another visa?
column2: You can obtain an I-20 form while in the United States on another visa if you are eligible to change your visa status to an F-1 student visa.

column1: Do I need health insurance to get an I-20 form?
column2: Health insurance is typically required for F-1 visa holders, and having health insurance coverage is essential for maintaining legal status and obtaining an I-20 form.

column1: How do I request a reduction in course load on my I-20 form?
column2: To request a reduction in course load on your I-20 form, you must consult with your designated school official (DSO) and provide valid reasons for the reduction as per immigration regulations.

column1: Can I transfer my I-20 form to another school at the same university?
column2: You can transfer your I-20 form to another school within the same university by following the transfer process outlined by the university's international student office.

column1: How can I obtain a program extension using my I-20 form?
column2: To obtain a program extension using your I-20 form, you must apply for an extension before the program end date and meet the eligibility requirements for the extension.

column1: Can I work on campus using my I-20 form?
column2: You can work on campus using your I-20 form, but employment opportunities are limited to on-campus jobs and must comply with the regulations set for F-1 visa holders.

column1: How can I apply for Optional Practical Training (OPT) using my I-20 form?
column2: Applying for Optional Practical Training (OPT) using your I-20 form involves submitting an OPT application to U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) through your designated school official (DSO).

column1: Can I travel outside of the United States while on OPT using my I-20 form?
column2: While on OPT, you can travel outside of the United States with your I-20 form, but ensure you have the necessary travel endorsements and documents for re-entry into the U.S.

column1: How do I amend my I-20 form if my address changes while on OPT?
column2: To amend your I-20 form if your address changes while on OPT, you should inform your designated school official (DSO) promptly to update the document with the new address details.

column1: Can I apply for a green card using my I-20 form?
column2: Applying for a green card involves a separate immigration process and is not directly related to your I-20 form; you would need to explore green card eligibility and application procedures.

column1: What if I lose my I-20 form?
column2: If you lose your I-20 form, you must contact your designated school official (DSO) immediately to request a replacement and follow the necessary steps to obtain a new form.

column1: Can I study at another university while on OPT using my I-20 form?

column1: What is the SEVIS cost, and why do I need to pay it?
column2: The SEVIS cost is associated with the Student and Exchange Visitor Information System (SEVIS) maintained by the U.S. government to track and monitor international students and exchange visitors during their stay in the United States.

column1: How much is the SEVIS charge, and how should I pay it?
column2: The SEVIS charge amount is set by the U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and is typically around $350 for F and M visa applicants, which must be paid before applying for a visa or entering the U.S.

column1: Is the SEVIS cost a one-time payment or do I have to pay it annually?
column2: The SEVIS fee is a one-time payment required for initial F or M visa applications and is not an annual fee, but students may need to pay it again if they transfer to a new school or change visa status.

column1: Can I pay the SEVIS fee using my home currency?
column2: The SEVIS fee must be paid in U.S. dollars, and international students can typically pay it using various methods such as online payment, bank drafts, international money orders, or Western Union Quick Pay services.

column1: If my visa is denied, is the SEVIS cost refundable?
column2: If a visa application is denied, the SEVIS fee is non-refundable, as it is a separate fee from the visa application fee and is used to maintain the SEVIS system regardless of visa approval.

column1: Can I pay the SEVIS charge after I arrive in the United States?
column2: The SEVIS fee must be paid before applying for a visa or entering the United States, typically through the SEVIS fee payment portal online, and it cannot be paid after arrival in the U.S.

column1: Can I pay my SEVIS fee at the US embassy or consulate?
column2: The SEVIS fee is paid online through the SEVIS fee payment portal, and it is not typically paid at the U.S. embassy or consulate during the visa application process.

column1: How long does it take for SEVIS fee payments to be processed?
column2: SEVIS fee payments are processed immediately upon successful payment, and students receive a confirmation of payment, which is required for the visa application process.

column1: Is the SEVIS fee payment associated with my visa application?
column2: The SEVIS fee payment is associated with the visa application process for F and M visa applicants, as proof of payment is required when applying for a visa and entering the United States.

column1: Does the SEVIS cost differ for different types of visas?
column2: The SEVIS fee amount is the same for different types of visas, such as F and M visas, and is set by the U.S. Department of Homeland Security for all international students and exchange visitors.

column1: Can I pay the SEVIS fee using a credit card?
column2: The SEVIS fee can typically be paid using a credit card, debit card, money order, check, or other accepted payment methods specified on the SEVIS fee payment portal.

column1: What happens if I don't pay my SEVIS fee?
column2: If the SEVIS fee is not paid, students may encounter delays in visa processing, inability to apply for a visa, or issues with maintaining legal status as an international student in the United States.

column1: Can I pay my SEVIS charge in installments?
column2: The SEVIS fee is a one-time payment and is not typically available for installment payments, as it must be paid in full before applying for a visa or entering the United States.

column1: Can I receive a receipt for my SEVIS fee payment?
column2: Students receive a receipt for their SEVIS fee payment upon successful completion of the payment transaction, which serves as proof of payment and is required for the visa application process and entry into the United States.

column1: Are there any discounts or waivers for the SEVIS fee?
column2: Discounts or waivers for the SEVIS fee are not typically available, as it is a mandatory fee set by the U.S. Department of Homeland Security for all international students and exchange visitors.

column1: May I pay the SEVIS charge online?
column2: Yes, the SEVIS charge is paid online through the SEVIS fee payment portal, allowing students to complete the payment electronically.

column1: Is there a deadline to pay the SEVIS fee?
column2: There is no specific deadline to pay the SEVIS fee, but it is recommended to pay it well before the visa application process to avoid delays in processing.

column1: Can I pay the SEVIS fee before receiving my I-20 or DS-2019 forms?
column2: Students can pay the SEVIS fee before receiving their I-20 or DS-2019 forms, as the fee payment is a prerequisite for the visa application process.

column1: Does the SEVIS cost differ for undergraduate and graduate students?
column2: The SEVIS fee is typically the same for undergraduate and graduate students, as it is a standard fee set by the U.S. Department of Homeland Security for all F and M visa applicants.

column1: Can I pay the SEVIS charge using a debit card?
column2: Payment methods for the SEVIS charge may include debit cards, credit cards, money orders, checks, or other approved payment options specified on the SEVIS fee payment portal.

column1: Are there any other fees or levies that come with the SEVIS fee?
column2: The SEVIS fee is a standalone fee and does not include additional costs or levies; it is a separate fee required for maintaining the Student and Exchange Visitor Information System.

column1: Can I get a refund if I change my mind about studying in the United States?
column2: The SEVIS fee is non-refundable, even if students change their minds about studying in the United States or encounter visa application issues.

column1: Can I pay my SEVIS fee through the university's website?
column2: The SEVIS fee must be paid through the SEVIS fee payment portal online and is not typically processed through the university's website.

column1: Is there a limit on the number of times I can pay the SEVIS fee?
column2: There is no limit on the number of times students can pay the SEVIS fee, but it is a one-time payment required for F and M visa applicants.

column1: Can I pay my SEVIS fee in person at a US embassy or consulate?
column2: The SEVIS fee cannot be paid in person at a U.S. embassy or consulate; it must be paid online through the SEVIS fee payment portal before the visa application process.

column1: Does the SEVIS cost differ for international transfer students?
column2: The SEVIS fee is typically the same for international transfer students, as it is a standard fee set by the U.S. Department of Homeland Security for all F and M visa applicants.

column1: Can I pay the SEVIS charge using a money order?
column2: Payment methods for the SEVIS charge may include money orders, in addition to debit cards, credit cards, checks, or other approved payment options specified on the SEVIS fee payment portal.

column1: Is the SEVIS charge included in my tuition costs?
column2: The SEVIS fee is a separate fee from tuition costs and is not included in the university's tuition fees; it is specifically for maintaining the Student and Exchange Visitor Information System.

column1: Do I need to pay the SEVIS fee if I'm moving schools within the US?
column2: If you are moving schools within the U.S., you may need to pay the SEVIS fee again if transferring to a new institution, as the fee is associated with the SEVIS record for each school.

column1: Can I pay the SEVIS fee before to my visa interview?
column2: While the SEVIS fee can be paid before the visa interview, it is recommended to complete this payment well in advance to avoid delays in the visa application process.

column1: Does SEVIS charge a separate cost for dependents?
column2: The SEVIS fee is typically per visa applicant and does not have a separate cost for dependents; each individual applying for an F or M visa must pay the SEVIS fee.

column1: Can I pay my SEVIS charge at a US airport upon arrival?
column2: The SEVIS fee cannot be paid at a U.S. airport upon arrival; it must be paid online through the SEVIS fee payment portal before entering the United States.

column1: Can I pay the SEVIS charge with a foreign check?
column2: Payment methods for the SEVIS charge may include foreign checks, in addition to debit cards, credit cards, money orders, or other approved payment options specified on the SEVIS fee payment portal.

column1: Are the SEVIS fees different for J-1 and F-1 visa holders?
column2: The SEVIS fees are the same for J-1 and F-1 visa holders, as the fee amount is set by the U.S. Department of Homeland Security for all international students and exchange visitors.

column1: Can I pay the SEVIS charge via bank transfer?
column2: Payments for the SEVIS charge are typically made online through the SEVIS fee payment portal and may not be available through bank transfers.

column1: Does the SEVIS charge differ for distance learning and online programs?
column2: The SEVIS fee amount is generally the same for all F and M visa applicants, regardless of whether the program is distance learning, online, or traditional in-person instruction.

column1: Can I pay the SEVIS fee using a prepaid card?
column2: Paying the SEVIS fee using a prepaid card may not be an accepted method of payment, as payment options are typically limited to credit cards, debit cards, money orders, or other specified payment methods.

column1: Can I pay the SEVIS charge with cash?
column2: Cash payments for the SEVIS charge are generally not accepted, as the fee is typically paid online through the SEVIS fee payment portal using electronic payment methods.

column1: Does the SEVIS cost differ for part-time students?

column1: What is Optional Practical Training (OPT) for overseas students studying artificial intelligence at university?
column2: Optional Practical Training (OPT) is a program that allows international students studying artificial intelligence at Yeshiva University to work in the United States for up to 12 months after completing their academic program. OPT provides students with an opportunity to gain practical work experience in their field of study, apply their skills in real-world settings, and enhance their professional development.

column1: How do international students pursuing AI studies apply for OPT?
column2: International students pursuing AI studies can apply for OPT by submitting Form I-765, Application for Employment Authorization, to U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS), along with the required supporting documents, fee payment, and endorsement from their designated school official. By following the OPT application process, students can obtain authorization to work in the United States for post-completion OPT or pre-completion OPT opportunities.

column1: What are the eligibility requirements for international students to participate in OPT for AI positions?
column2: The eligibility requirements for international students to participate in OPT for AI positions at Yeshiva University include being in valid F-1 status, completing at least one academic year of full-time study, maintaining good academic standing, and receiving approval from their designated school official. By meeting the OPT eligibility criteria, students can apply for authorization to work in the U.S. and gain practical experience in their field of study.

column1: What is the period of OPT for international students in AI programs?

Students may also be eligible for a 24-month STEM OPT extension if their degree program is in a STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, Mathematics) field, such as artificial intelligence. This extension provides students with additional time to gain practical work experience in the U.S. and further their professional development in AI-related positions.

column1: Who is Dr. Avi H. Giloni?
column2: Dr. Avi H. Giloni is the Associate Dean, Chair of the Information and Decision Sciences Department, and a Professor of Operations Management and Statistics at the Sy Syms School of Business. He holds a PhD in statistics and operations research from the Leonard Stern School of Business at New York University. Dr. Giloni is known for his expertise in operations management and statistics, emphasizing understanding and modeling randomness and risk. His research interests include robust forecasting, optimization, stochastic system design, and their applications in supply chain management.

column1: What educational background does Dr. Avi H. Giloni have?
column2: Dr. Avi H. Giloni has an extensive educational background from the Stern School of Business at New York University, including a PhD (2000), MPhil (1998), and MS (1997). He also holds a BA from the College of Arts and Science at NYU, earned in 1994.

column1: What are Dr. Avi H. Giloni’s teaching and research interests?
column2: Dr. Avi H. Giloni is passionate about teaching courses in Operations Management and Statistics, focusing on students' understanding and modeling of randomness and risk. His research interests are primarily in robust forecasting, optimization, and stochastic system design, with a particular application in supply chain management.

column1: Can you list some publications by Dr. Avi H. Giloni?
column2: Yes, Dr. Avi H. Giloni has co-authored several articles, including “Neo-Rawlsian Fringes: A New Approach to Market Segmentation and New Product Development,” “Mathematical Programming Approach for Improving the Robustness of LAD Regression,” “Robust Weighted LAD Regression,” “Robust Analysis of Variance: Process Design and Quality Improvement,” and “Information Sharing in a Supply Chain Under ARMA Demand.”

column2: Dr. Avi H. Giloni’s email address is agiloni@yu.edu.
